item.title: In The Age Of Digital Medicine, The Humble Reflex Hammer Hangs On
item.description: May 28, 2017 - Nearly 130 years since its inception, a modest knob of rubber with a metal handle is still invaluable in diagnosing disease and avoiding expensive testing. But its history is anything but simple.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 28, 2017 - Nearly 130 years since its inception, a modest knob of rubber with a metal handle is still invaluable in diagnosing disease and avoiding expensive testing. But its history is anything but simple. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/28/529821714/in-the-age-of-digital-medicine-the-humble-reflex-hammer-hangs-on

item.title: How A Gene Editing Tool Went From Labs To A Middle-School Classroom
item.description: May 27, 2017 - Some compare the democratization of personal computing in the 1970s to the current changes in access to genetic engineering tools, in part thanks to the CRISPR gene editing tool.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 27, 2017 - Some compare the democratization of personal computing in the 1970s to the current changes in access to genetic engineering tools, in part thanks to the CRISPR gene editing tool. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/05/27/530210657/how-a-gene-editing-tool-went-from-labs-to-a-middle-school-classroom

item.title: Two Sisters Try To Tackle Drug Use At A Montana Indian Reservation
item.description: May 27, 2017 - With a lack of treatment options at the Fort Belknap reservation, the pair has sparked a grassroots response to substance abuse by creating peer support groups — the only choice for many seeking help.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 27, 2017 - With a lack of treatment options at the Fort Belknap reservation, the pair has sparked a grassroots response to substance abuse by creating peer support groups — the only choice for many seeking help. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/27/529112467/two-sisters-try-to-tackle-drug-use-at-a-montana-indian-reservation

item.title: In Arizona, Doctors Criticize Tightening Of Late Abortion Rules
item.description: May 26, 2017 - Many states have laws about what to do if there are signs of life after an abortion. But Arizona legislators have passed new rules that some doctors say go against national standards of care.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 26, 2017 - Many states have laws about what to do if there are signs of life after an abortion. But Arizona legislators have passed new rules that some doctors say go against national standards of care. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/26/530257471/in-arizona-doctors-criticize-tightening-of-late-abortion-rules

item.title: As Nursing Homes Evict Patients, States Question Motives
item.description: May 26, 2017 - According to the federal government, the top complaint about nursing homes is wrongful eviction. Advocates say nursing homes want residents who pay more but require less care.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 26, 2017 - According to the federal government, the top complaint about nursing homes is wrongful eviction. Advocates say nursing homes want residents who pay more but require less care. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/26/529915765/states-try-to-keep-nursing-homes-from-kicking-out-less-lucrative-patients

item.title: As Brains Mature, More Robust Information Networks Boost Self-Control
item.description: May 26, 2017 - Sometime between grade school and grad school, the brain's information highways get remapped in a way that dramatically reins in impulsive behavior.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 26, 2017 - Sometime between grade school and grad school, the brain's information highways get remapped in a way that dramatically reins in impulsive behavior. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/26/529828305/more-robust-information-networks-boost-self-control-as-brains-mature

item.title: This 3-Year-Old's Murder Is Part Of South Africa's Alarming 'Epidemic'
item.description: May 26, 2017 - Courtney Pieters' death this month made headlines and sparked an outcry. The country is only now beginning to address its high rate of child murder.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 26, 2017 - Courtney Pieters' death this month made headlines and sparked an outcry. The country is only now beginning to address its high rate of child murder. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/05/26/530011693/this-3-year-olds-murder-is-part-of-south-africa-s-alarming-epidemic

item.title: Can Comfort Care At The ER Help Older People Live Longer And Suffer Less?
item.description: May 26, 2017 - Many older patients have problems that an emergency room is ill-equipped to handle, but often there is nowhere else to go. So some hospitals are adding palliative care consultants to the front lines.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 26, 2017 - Many older patients have problems that an emergency room is ill-equipped to handle, but often there is nowhere else to go. So some hospitals are adding palliative care consultants to the front lines. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/26/530012837/can-comfort-care-at-the-er-help-older-people-live-longer-and-suffer-less

item.title: Do You Know What Red Nose Day Is?
item.description:
May 25, 2017 - The name may be silly, but Red Nose Day — which is today — has a serious mission. How do charity evaluators size up this campaign?
- http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/05/25/529868226/do-you-know-what-red-nose-day-is
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Trump's Proposed Budget Would Cut $2.2 Billion From Global Health Spending
item.description: May 25, 2017 - The administration wants to reduce the current $8.7 billion global health budget by about 26 percent. Family planning programs would be the hardest hit.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 25, 2017 - The administration wants to reduce the current $8.7 billion global health budget by about 26 percent. Family planning programs would be the hardest hit. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/05/25/529873431/trumps-proposed-budget-would-cut-2-2-billion-from-global-health-spending

item.title: Many Adults Don't Think Exposure To Vaping Is Bad For Kids
item.description: May 25, 2017 - Nicotine, heavy metals and tiny particles that can harm the lungs float around in the aerosol from e-cigarettes. But a survey finds many adults don't think secondhand vape is dangerous for children.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 25, 2017 - Nicotine, heavy metals and tiny particles that can harm the lungs float around in the aerosol from e-cigarettes. But a survey finds many adults don't think secondhand vape is dangerous for children. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/25/530026958/many-adults-dont-think-exposure-to-vaping-is-bad-for-kids

item.title: Patient, Doctor Groups Say New CBO Score Reveals Health Care Bill's Flaws
item.description: May 25, 2017 - The latest analysis by the Congressional Budget Office says the bill would lead to 23 million fewer people having insurance coverage and would cut the federal deficit by $119 billion over 10 years.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 25, 2017 - The latest analysis by the Congressional Budget Office says the bill would lead to 23 million fewer people having insurance coverage and would cut the federal deficit by $119 billion over 10 years. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/25/529909663/patient-doctor-groups-say-new-cbo-score-reveals-health-bills-flaws

item.title: Eating Chocolate, A Little Each Week, May Lower The Risk Of A Heart Flutter
item.description: May 24, 2017 - The latest evidence that a chocolate habit may lower your risk of heart disease: A study finds people who ate small amounts of chocolate several times a week had a lower risk of atrial fibrillation.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - The latest evidence that a chocolate habit may lower your risk of heart disease: A study finds people who ate small amounts of chocolate several times a week had a lower risk of atrial fibrillation. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/24/529843647/eating-chocolate-a-little-each-week-may-lower-the-risk-of-a-heart-flutter

item.title: Trump Wants Families On Food Stamps To Get Jobs. The Majority Already Work
item.description: May 24, 2017 - Some 55 percent of families with kids on SNAP have jobs — they just don't earn enough to live on. Many states where reliance on SNAP is heaviest voted overwhelmingly for Trump last November.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - Some 55 percent of families with kids on SNAP have jobs — they just don't earn enough to live on. Many states where reliance on SNAP is heaviest voted overwhelmingly for Trump last November. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/24/529831472/trump-wants-families-on-food-stamps-to-get-jobs-the-majority-already-work

item.title: CBO Releases Score For House-Approved American Health Care Act
item.description: May 24, 2017 - The Congressional Budget Office gave its projections Wednesday on the costs and impact of the version of the American Health Care Act passed by the House earlier this month.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - The Congressional Budget Office gave its projections Wednesday on the costs and impact of the version of the American Health Care Act passed by the House earlier this month. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/24/529893114/cbo-releases-score-for-house-approved-american-health-care-act
